data.q: Which Node.js module is used to spawn child processes?
data.e: The child_process module provides functions to spawn and manage child processes.

data.q: Which method is used to execute a shell command in Node.js?
data.e: exec() runs a shell command and buffers the output.

data.q: What is the difference between spawn() and exec() in Node.js?
o: spawn buffers output, exec streams output
spawn streams output, exec buffers output
data.e: spawn() streams output as data events, while exec() buffers the entire output before returning.

data.q: Which method is used to create a new Node.js process that runs a module?
data.e: fork() creates a new Node.js process specifically to run a module.

data.q: Which module enables multithreading in Node.js?
data.e: The worker_threads module allows running JavaScript in parallel threads.

data.q: What is the purpose of the 'message' event in child processes?
o: To send signals to the OS
To communicate between parent and child processes
data.e: The 'message' event is used for IPC (inter-process communication) between parent and child processes.

data.q: Which method is used to send a message from a parent process to a child process?
data.e: The send() method is used to send messages from parent to child processes.

data.q: What is the main difference between cluster and worker_threads?
o: cluster uses multiple processes, worker_threads use multiple threads
cluster uses threads, worker_threads use processes
data.e: Cluster creates multiple Node.js processes, while worker_threads create multiple threads within a single process.

data.q: Which property of a child process object gives access to its standard output?
data.e: child.stdout provides access to the standard output stream of the child process.

data.q: What happens if a child process is not properly handled?
o: It may remain running and cause resource leaks
data.e: Unmanaged child processes may remain running, consuming system resources and causing leaks.
